data.commitMessage:
FAB-266 TCert lib Partial impl.

The implementation is non-HSM friendly where TCerts are generated
based on Key Derivation function.This implements FAB-873 and
FAB-876.

FAB-873 Crypto Support for TCert Genertion.
     https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-873

FAB-876 As an application developer , I want to generate TCert locally
based on ECert that I have or got from CoP sevice
     https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-876

Support for Elliptic Curve and RSA for TCert. Support for TCert
Generation locally given all paramters necessary to generate TCert is
being passed from calling application.This will be extended to support
TCert on COP Server in next code drop.

Change-Id: I904e5684d8a66e100f13ddd349399ebb86601631
Signed-off-by: ASHUTOSH KUMAR <ashutosh_kumar@hotmail.com>

comments.message:
We should not have hard-coded file names.  As we discussed, this should be written as a library which has functions which must be called to set configuration items. When this runs inside the COP server, the cli/server/config.go or cli/server/server.go files can then be modified to call into the library to set any required configuration items.  This will avoid any import cycles and also make this as reusable as possible.
In this case, you should be using the BCCSP APIs, which means you should have a configuration function similar to the following:
    func SetSigningKey(key Key)
where Key is defined in fabric/core/crypto/bccsp.go
This is a valid point. I am looking into BCCSP now.

This is the main call to the library to get a batch of tcerts, right?  Pls document the API.  What exactly is the format of the 'jsonString' and 'signatureString', and format of the return string also.

Also wondering why you're not defining a struct as input rather than a json string.  The struct would be self-defining.

Will make this change , although to me it seems more like bookkeeping. 

This API is for external consumption and I had plans for coming up with swagger definition for this and hence did not define it internally.
Looks to be hard-coded for ecdsa 384.  We need to support all key sizes supported by BCCSP, and should be using BCCSP APIs where possible and needed to support HSM.
It was under my plan for next code drop. My initial focus was to have basic functionality working. Like I said before , I am looking into BCCSP.
will remove it in next code drop.
So it looks like you are parsing jsonString each time you need to extract a value from it.  It would be much more efficient to define a struct and just reference fields.
This assumes the CN is the enrollment ID which may not always be the case.  Pls define a utility function so this is localized and can be changed as needed in future.

As discussed, this should be written as a library with functions to set any config items.  The code in fabric-cop/cli/server/config.go can then call these functions based on values in the server's config to initialize your library.

In this case though, we need to use BCCSP APIs as defined in fabric/core/crypto/bccsp/bccsp.go.  In particular, see the Key interface.  So this tcert library should I think have a function similar to:
    func SetSignerKey(key Key)
where Key is the BCCSP Key interface.

I think a better name for this function is GetTCertBatch or something similar since we call it that elsewhere.
Also, pls define two functions:
1) GetTCertBatch which takes a pointer to GetTCertBatchRequest struct as an argument and returns a pointer to a GetTCertBatchResponse struct as output.  Using structs is self-documenting and also more efficient than reparsing a JSON string everytime you want to extract a field.
2) GetTCertBatchJSON which takes a single json string as input and returns json string as output.  This function simply deserializes the input json, calls GetTCertBatch, and serializes the output struct to json.

You are hardcoded to support ecdsa 384 only here.
You should be using BCCSP APIs as much as possible, and where you can't, we should discuss enhancing BCCSP.  This provides the needed abstraction and should support multiple algorithms and key sizes.
Makes sense. Like I said before , I am looking into BCCSP APIs.
What is the "123" here?  Shouldn't be hardcoded I assume.
You are right. I need to think more to see , if we need it. Regardless , I'll fix it in next code drop.

This assumes the CN of a cert is always the enrollment ID.  This may not always be the case in the future.  I suggest making defining an API similar to the following.  For now, I suggest defining a single function similar to:
    func GetEnrollmentIDFromCert(cert *x509.Certificate) string
and using it everywhere you need to extract it in case we need to change it later.  Even if this is the only place it is called, it would still be helpful to do this.
What is this file?  I assume you didn't mean to check it in.
I meant to check-in for a test that checks for non x509 format of file as certificate.
Let's start with a capital P, but more importantly, a user (providing a string privateKey?) would not necessarily understand/comprehend the error message (mentioning "block")
This file is deleted. I have moved it under lib/crypto.
Let's clean these up a bit?
This file has been deleted from util directory and and is moved under lib/crypto.
Why are you not return()-ing here, unlike above and below?
This file has been deleted from util directory and and is moved under lib/crypto.
This file is deleted. I have moved it under lib/crypto.

It seems to me that we should have a much smaller change set which just start with the implementation of this library for basic tcert generation.  We should just have a simple call which takes the required inputs (e.g. ecert, index, numInBatch, optional attributes)

That is correct and this is the change set which captures what you have alluded. Once Pho checks-in DB part , I am going to integrate that piece. Also per Keith comments , I am working on BCCSP integration as we speak.

this seems to have a lot more "wrapper" stuff than just a basic input / output library.  Perhaps it's because there is a ton of code for parsing JSON?   I guess I am not so sure that the function methods here should take JSON as input?

This API will be called from client , say , node and hence I started with JSON as input as that can flow over wire with client and server being decoupled. Per Keith's suggestion , I am going to do mapping of json to struct. So the client will pass Json as input , we'll have another wrapper , which will convert JSON to struct and then call another method which takes json struct as input. Does that make sense ?
Amen nearly 3k LOC is really unacceptable

I have made changes in patch set 9 where input from external entity is json string. The json string is getting converted into struct which is passed around internally.Please let me know , if that is not ok.
That is the minimum number of code required to make it logical unit.I am going to put smallest change set possible going forward. Any suggestion for small changeset is welcome.

data.commitMessage:
Adding TCert Library API

This is step 2 of adding TCert support to
the COP server.  In particular, the main
API is the GetBatch function in tcert.go.
All other functions support this main function.

There are two other pieces of work which will
come in future change sets:
1) integrate this into the COP server by calling
   the GetBatch function;
2) bccsp integration.  Note that until this is
   done, there are some hard-coded crypto values,
   but this is only temporary.

See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-876

Change-Id: I9eab8af2b6840865eaf4e4aa84458c2a1c535a1e
Signed-off-by: ASHUTOSH KUMAR <ashutosh_kumar@hotmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

comments.message:
"This is set to 1 , if this filed is absent.Required field"

1. Add a space before This.
2. filed -> field. 
3. Please decide if it is a Required field, then we don't have to set it to 1 if it is absent. If it's optional, then remove the Required.

Indeed/probably having it as a "required" field makes it clearer for the user, and feels a bit more in "control", such as: "Please get me 10 TCerts"

"AttributeEncryptionEnabled"
>>
"EncryptAttributes"

// When set to true, each issued TCert in the batch will contain encrypted attributes

Or

// When set to true, the X509 extensions/attributes will be encrypted in the issued TCerts
TCert encapsulates a signed transaction certificate and optionally, a map of keys

On that note, we should probably call the configuration parameter MaxAllowedBatchSize.

---

Again, less "magic", more explicit/intuitive/deterministic/clear/transparent behavior.

I suggest the following logic:

1. If a consumer asks for 0 TCerts then
   the MaxBatchSize is returned.
2. If 0 < count <= MaxBatchSize then
   return count TCerts
3. If MaxBatchSize < count then
   return an error as part of the response (explaining that requests cannot exceed the maximum allowed batch size.
I think , 1 should be : If the consumer asks for 0 Tcerts , then 1 TCert will be returned.
Ash, I agree that Jonathan's suggestion is more flexible for a user.  It gives them the opportunity to return the max possible while also knowing if they explicitly request too many.
Agree. Will make change in future patch.
// The top-level pre-key to be used for key derivation
Agree , will make change in future change set.
TCert encapsulates a signed transaction certificate and optionally a map of keys
Sounds good. Will make change in future change set.

hmm - so you can request an attribute by the name as well as by name and value?  Meaning if I ask for attribute attr1 the tcert will be populated with whatever the stored values of that attribute are?  And if I ask for attr1 / value1 if will only be populated if attr1=value1?

If not, we should remove value

The message definition contains message that will be coming over the wire and one that will be fed by internal system , say , DB of CoP Server. AttrNames will be coming over the wire and Attrs will be coming from CoP Server.Here the the flow : 
1) Client makes a call for Batch of TCerts by passing Uid and name of attributes that are being passed.The data is being transferred in JSON format.
2) CoP Server validate the user and then returns attribute name and value for attributes that are being passed.This returned attribute name and value is being fed into TCert API. This flow corresponds to internal system-to-system flow within CoP Server. JSON struct not being present for Attribute Name and Attribute Value  means that Attribute Name and Attribute Value is not allowed to be passed in from system external to CoP.

My original plan was to have Attrs should also be coming over the wire by enabling corresponding json value to cater to scenario where the client does not want to call CoP server at all. In that case , if client makes local query , say , LDAP query to get attribute name and value and pass them in TCert API call , TCert API will put those TCERTs into TCert. Please let me know your thoughts on this.

Please comment further on this.

Good catch.  This was a mistake.  Attr names flow over the wire which is defined by GetPrivateSignersRequest in idp.go (which by the way will be renamed in a future change set and simplified).  The server then looks up the value and passes name/val pairs to the tcert library, so names shouldn't have been here.

It should  probably be: if the requested (number of TCerts) is higher than the Max... 

But instead, please let's remove this line (as per the previous exchange, at https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3309/3/lib/tcert/api.go)
This was intentional Ash.  This is the default constructor but can be overridden with a different template setting.

I understand , providing default constructor is good programming practice. But the default assignment abobe does not seem right. Template encapsulate certificate data that goes into TCert and CA Cert corresponds to CA who signs Tcert. These 2 are two different entity which cannot be equated. Above assignment gives an illusion of producing self signed cert , whereas in reality it does not.Please revert the change back to what was in original change set. Thanks.

Good point Ash.  It can't look like a self-signed cert and in this case, it would appear that way.  That made me look more closely at the logic.  Two points:
1) The GetBatch function was not thread-safe.  Multiple threads could modify the template at the same time, screwing up the logic.
2) Given the purpose of a TCert is to be anonymous and unlinkable, there is no reason to give an administrator the ability to configure the template anyway, so I removed it.  Instead, I just create an empty x509.Certificate each time GetBatch is called.  This fixes the issue in #1 and also makes the library easier to use.
Keith , please initialize template variable that was in original change set.
In the test case in previous, we were using the CA cert so it is the same.
We might want to put O as Hyperledger.org also , but that is benign. I am fine with what is there.
Nit - but I would use "Fabric Transaction Certificate" rather than "COP ..."

I suggest either HLF Transaction Certificate or Fabric Transaction Certificate.

Ash, feel free to add things you believe should be added to this/your changeset, or alternatively, you can of course always follow up with another one. Separately, may be quicker to evaluate/merge, I presume.
Oh, yes, let's do "Fabric Transaction Certificate" then, sorry.
Please let's update the comment, now that the logic has changed...

I don't like the variable name "num".

Let's either use something more meaningful to represent the number of TCerts in the batch, or alternatively, one would argue that you don't need a "temporary" / "copy" there in the first place (now that we are not overwriting the request's "count" parameter's value...)
Please remove this line about the "Persistence Part"

//var cooked string

OK... the let's remove this line.
Let's make this a one line comment

data.commitMessage:
Adding TCert Option 2 Library API

This implements FAB 1479
API for HSM Friendly TCert Generation
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1479

This implements FAB 1477 also
Crypto support for HSM Friedly TCert generation
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1477
This has BCCSP integration

One major change in this patch set is :
Client needs to specify which block was
signed and provide data in byte format and
put that in block with Public Key and Signature.
Client is expected to sign GetPrivateSignerRequest

Changed BCCSP element of TCertManager to be exportable
so that I can use it from CoP Server.

Added Method BatchRequestToPubkeyBuff in lib/tcert/util.go
to support TCert CoP server integration.

TCert integration to CoP Client and Server follows

Change-Id: I23af79fe84e30ad193516c1e6a6bc4b094613c5e
Signed-off-by: ASHUTOSH KUMAR <ashutosh_kumar@hotmail.com>

comments.message:
"contains TCert request where public key is being provided by caller" 
-->
"GetBatchGenKeyRequest encapsulates a (TCert) BatchRequest with corresponding PublicKeys "

I think the name "GetBatchGenKeyRequest" is a bit confusing since it sounds like it will generate keys which is actually what option 1 does, but it is instead using already generated keys.  I suggest naming it "GetBatchForKeysRequest".

Add a comment similar to:
"Return a TCert for each public key in the PublicKeys array.  The BatchRequest.Count field is ignored."

"TCert Generation Failed with error "
--->
"Failed to generate a Transaction Certificate (TCert)"
You are telling to suppress the error and give just an error statement ? Please let me know.

No, not at all. I suggest to correct the preceding text:

Please change the selected/quoted/highlighted text with the proposed text only. Leave the rest as is, thanks.

log.Errorf("Failed to generate a Transaction Certificate (TCert) [%v]", certError)
You can reuse the same string/error message, by calling sprint(), once.

You don't need to declare this outside of the if clause/block.
"enrollmentIDerr" is used in lines 272-273. You can instead create a temporary these.

Looking at code more closely , I came to conclusion that I cannot change the code. Error is being later in the code.encEnrollmentID is being used in line 322 , which is outside of the block.Also , I need to get error from the call CBCPKCS7Encrypt at line 270. If I have to declare one variable , encEnrollmentID outside the block , I need to declare second one also outside of the block.

You are returning an unused/uninitialized variable "err" here...
1. I believe you meant/should return "enrollmentIDerr" here?
2. Please remove the declaration of "err" from line 260.

Use constant here.
Is this the constant that a user will need to use in order to get the enrollment ID from a tcert?
We should have a test case which decrypts the enrollment ID.
Done. Test case has been added.

Do we cover this in tests? Otherwise, can we add a test that covered these two flows?

That is, one with the "current" logic, of not checking if enrollmentCert is nil, and one with enrollmentCert that is not nil here?
We have test to cover both flows and I tested those out before check-in. For TCert option 1 , we are using enrollment cert and TCert option 2 , we are not using enrollment cert.

I don't understand what is "TCert option 1" and what is "TCert option 2".

Can we put in JIRA what happens or should happen if one is asking for a batch of TCerts or the developer is calling generateExtensions() without providing an ECert?

TCert option 1 is what has been done on Fabric 0.6. The API name in GetBatch. Hardware HSM does not support this mechanism and hence Zuric Research team came up with another mechanism where key derivation is not required. I have updated FAB 1372 with implementation details for TCert option2, link of which is : https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1372. The link has some background on TCert option #1 as well.
Is there not a lint error here (function name mismatch?)
Lint does not care for Test files and hence no error was thrown.
OK, thanks. Please let's correct it.
Do you want to use the same error message for logging and in the returned values.... ?
That is what I was thinking. I am open for suggestion/improvements.

Apologies for phrasing this in a semi-convoluted way. When I wrote:
"Do you want to use the same error message for logging and in the returned values.... ?"

I meant to say: "Please change these two lines, so that the same error message is used for logging and and as the returned value from the function." Currently they are not the same: 

		log.Errorf("Certificate Creation failed with error [%v]", err)
		return nil, fmt.Errorf("Failed in TCert x509.CreateCertificate: %s", err)

Thanks.
Not sure if this is clear...
Will change it to : GetPublicKey returns ecdsa or RSA public key for the public key buffer.

1. Probably a better name for the function would be:: Bytes2PublicKey() or BytesToPublicKey()

2. "Byte2PublicKey parses a DER encoded public key (or a PEM block), returning an x509 PublicKey interface"

We don't need this.  We can just add another optional field to the "GetPrivateSignersRequest" struct above similar to:

    KeySigPairs []KeySigPair `json:"key_sig_pairs,omitempty"

This allows us to use the existing endpoint as I don't see any reason to have to add a new endpoint.
OK. Good point.I'll make the change. So , the struc
We really want a union here, but since go doesn't have one, I guess this is OK.  Some validation is required to make sure exactly one of these is set.
Right now , I am checking for ECSignature.
Here also, I think you should just add an additional optional field to GetBatchRequest
I suggest defining one constant named "enrollmentIDKey" and using it for both the encryption key and map key.  Is there any reason they need to be different?

enrollmentID is being used to create encryption key for enrollment Id and enrollmentIDMapKey is key for map. enrollmentIDMapKey is going to be made public , but we do not want enrollmentID to be be exposed. Hence there are two different constants/variables.
This was inherited from merge conflict resolution. Will make change.
Why don't you just print the errorMessage that you have constructed in the previous line (with Sprint()) ? That is, please remove line 184.

will work.

Please rename this to cert_testing (or something that's different than the package you are testing.
I am following the pattern that is prevalent all across fabric-cop. In fabric-cop , test code and main code are in same package. What is the rational behind this proposal ? Please let me know.
Sorry, "tcert_test" preferably - so that it will be compiled as a separate package, and then linked and run with the main test binary. It's good practice, to test using a separate package.

I will not mind doing it if it is prevalent across whole of CoP. Like I said before , in cop , test code and functional code is in the same package. Keith or Gari has to chime in here as it has widespread CoP repercussions.

I see. That's a great point. I guess one can only imagine the "widespread COP repercussions", the consequences, and the  ramifications  of, G-d forbid, separating the code testing a module, from the module that is being tested.

It's OK, leave it.

Please could you kindly focus on addressing the other, much less risky, pending items in this review? Thanks
there's no repercussions only goodness as "blackbox" testing (i.e. tests are in a different package) are the recommended way to test packages which will be consumed by other packages
Thanks Gari for your input. Let me incorporate other comments in next patch set and will come back to this later. Does this make sense ? I am fine either way.
Let's be consistent with "TCert" rather than "Tcert" in these names.

"Enrollment ID cannot be retrieved with error"

"EnrollmentID could not be retrieved. Error returned: [%v]"

I had actually been asking that we use the following form for consistency ... at least that is what we've doing elsewhere.

t.Errorf("Error retrieving enrollment ID: %s", err)

I think we may need to make a pass thru everything to make the format of all errors consistent.  Perhaps we should just open a Jira item for that, but I agree that all new errors should be consistent to minimize clean up.

Oh, sure.

"Enrollment ID cannot be retrieved with error [%v]" sounds like/conveyed a different message (to me) - as if the attempt was "to retrieve the EID with an error" in the first place ;-)

Let's be consistent. ( Enrollment ID + Enrollment Id ) --> EnrollmentID

E.g. what are the possible returned values from GetEnrollmentIDFromCert() ?
The count of TCert is hard coded in the test data , hence I had to match up in error message. This is test code anyways. I am open for suggestions. What do you recommend ?
I inherited this from merge conflict resolution. Will Capitalize per your suggestion.
Sorry, I don't see the corrected version.
Is this an old comment?  Delete?

I really don't think we should be logging errors AND returning the same error message in an error.  The error response will be logged or consumed in another error that will be logged, so it just ends up with duplicate info in the logs.
You know that you can reuse the "err" variable, right?  I think it makes for cleaner reading code (i.e. not as verbose) than declaring variables for each error.  That is the pattern I see in go code.
I do not see any problem with this implementation.
Please grep for "Tcert" and change to "TCert"

The client should sign the exact bytes that are the body of the POST request flowing over the wire.  Sprintf is not necessarily going to return the same bytes.  You should pass the body of the POST request received by the server to this method to use in signature verification.

Let's use a different name for this package please.
Maybe "tcert_testing" ?
Same comment as in tcert_test.go. Also , We cannot have 2 packages in one directory in go.
This conflict with BCCSP change when the caKeyFile is an SKI file. https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3735/
I agree. Will be leveraging BCCSP SKI.

This is the same operation as in my comment bellow, candidate for BCCSP.. probably item for another workitem, since this is "option 1". It will also need https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4049/1 to be merged to be fully BCCSP-converted

Example use: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/bccsp/sw/impl_test.go#L1085

Further down in that test, there is also an example on CBCPKCS7Encrypt()

This looks like a useful switch-statement.. perhaps should had been offered by BCCSP.. Still, split it out to a separate function for now?

i.e case "SHA2_256": return &bccsp.SHA256Opts{}
     case "SHA2_384": return &bccsp.SHA384Opts{}
     ... and so on..

That way your code is much slimmer:

     digest, digestError = tm.bccsp.Hash(message, getHashOptsFromName(hashAlgo))

Havent found such a helper function in bccsp implementation.. would had been a good idea. if you move it out, will propose to Angelo.

data.commitMessage:
Retrieving Attributes from TCert

This implements FAB 1594
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1594

File names have been changed.

API has been changed.
New set of APIs have been introduced.

Caller has to instantiate AttributeManager
and call APIs.

Change-Id: I02c7a656febc6446f933e7e5940adb90e12a4a39
Signed-off-by: ASHUTOSH KUMAR <ashutosh_kumar@hotmail.com>

comments.message:
This is an API used by chaincode.  A better API would be to return an Attributes object from GetAttributesFromTCert.  The Attributes object has two methods:
1) GetNames()
2) GetValue(name string)
The decryption of a value (if encrypted) is done in GetValue.
This is more efficient if cases where chaincode may not need to decrypt all values.
Keith , I have updated JIRA https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1594 , with your comment.Can you please look into that and see , if it is correct ? Thanks in advance.

OK, this is a good example to something that I have discussed recently:

Someone calls GetAttributesFromTCert, but it fails. Looking at the returned error, he/she reads "Certificate cannot be created".

Do you see how this (can be) puzzling? I/one would go thinking: "hmmm, all I asked was to retrieve an attribute list and I have provided a certificate... why is COP attempting to create yet another one?"

Do you see what I mean by "the error should be more informative/actionable, whenever/as-much-as possible."
Do not throw away the original error
Please look at my comment above. Let me know , if you agree.
Based on my conversation with Keith Smith , I am going to throw error so that caller will catch the error and act upon it.
I was not sure about which log package to use. Will use CFSSL log package.
ok. Will handle error the way I described above.

Be consistent with how error messages are nested elsewhere in cop ... "message: %s", err
Also should include attributeName in this error message for context
will do. %v and %s will have same affect , right ? Do you have preference of %v over %s and vice versa ?

Please keep the capitalization consistent... see what you have just 5 lines above.
No reason to use "Batch"
use different error message from previous
== 0 has no effect because of != 2 comparison.  Why not 1?  I only see 1 attr in the pem file.
There are 2 attributes in PEM file. I was thinking about having check for absence of attributes and if attributes are present , the number of attributes should be 2. I guess , I'll keep !=2.

data.subject: Retrieving Attributes from TCert

data.commitMessage:
Address FAB-1454 add docker image for fabric-cop

Add creation of docker image for fabric-cop, essentially
transposed from fabric docker image build process.

Change-Id: Id26e53e705e289515e9ce28af3df534123f463de
Signed-off-by: Christopher Ferris <chrisfer@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: This should be "hyperledger/fabric-cop", I think.  Not sure it will matter as $(PROJECT_NAME) may not be used in this context, but still a dangling reference.
there was some odd circular logic that I think I have untangled - fixed

Suggest dropping the .baseimage-release file and just setting this explicitly in the Makefile.  It was a separate file in fabric so that it could be easily shared between vagrant and docker, which afaict doesnt apply here.
I am in total agreement, just did this for consistency with fabric...

$(TARGET) was created so we could generalize the rule with a wildcard.  e.g. "build/docker/bin/%".  Since this ported rule doesnt use wildcarding, we should probably at least be consistent.  E.g. either s/$(TARGET)/cop or put the wildcard back into the rule.
actually, for some odd reason they named the directory cli but the binary is named cop. See the native build (target 'cop').

I see that we are setting $COP_HOME, but are not installing any configuration.  If this is an area for cop to use at runtime for writing, as opposed to reading config, I would suggest pointing COP_HOME to something under /var (e.g. /var/hyperledger/fabric/cop)
This isn't strictly needed, but not a big deal if we want the place holder

data.commitMessage:
The reenroll command is incorrect in README

The ../testdata/csr.json should be as a last argument
when run reenroll command in README file

Change-Id: Ie675ca3d37bed1a8add081c889e8162c9bd22da5
Signed-off-by: David Geng <david@esse.io>

comments.message: Thanks, this is correct, but you can optionally pass "../testdata/csr.json" as a last argument.  I suggest adding another example below, stating that the CSR file argument is optional.

I have a little confusing about this CSR file argument, does it mean, we support to change the signature algorithm or org info when  reenroll the certificate?

I am not sure if the new enrollment cer and key could co-work with other existing certificate, can you help to confirm that?

Yes, this allows a user to reenroll with a different organization for example if needed.  The 1st ecert would be replaced by the 2nd.  But the enrollment ID must not change.  This means the CN must be the same in the CSR as the caller's enrollment ID.

Should not we give generic error message to user and log message for debugging purposes ?
Please will it be possible to start each printed sentence with a capital letter?

We should probably check the returned error, prior to using the returned "body"...
You should probably move the check in line 127-129 one line up.

Noting that you are overwriting the err returned from the Unmarshaling...
We are entering the 'else' clause if either "err != nil"... or [if len() <= 0 ]

Is this OK? We might want to simulate/add a few tests to verify these.

1. Capital S (for Server). Sorry ;-)... but more importantly,

2. I'm not sure it is "Server error", since we are in the client, etc..

The standard states for example that 400+ class of status code is "intended for situations in which the client seems to have erred." ...but I know what you mean. You refer to cases where the server response is, say, non-compliant AND when Status is not OK ? If I got this right, then see 3) below:

3. We are overriding err here. How about we print out the response (and not only the error from json.Unmarshal())
Does port needs to be hard coded ? Can we make it configurable ?

Keith: even if we choose not to have it configurable at this point, we can put it in a variable so that it's clearer (e.g. that port 8888 is being used)
This was code that I copied from CFSSL.  The default port for CFSSL is 8888.  I'll make this a const along with a comment.
Just to check: Is this the preferred logic? (e.g., if the scheme was not specified, then we use "http" ?
This was from CFSSL.  I'd be hesitant to change it without understanding fully any reprocussions.

Just a small question if I may- is there a PR on https://github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/pulls to add this method? because if there isn't- each time we update the folder in the vendor, it'd break the build, and we'll need to do a new PR here on gerrit.

I don't believe we should be changing the code under the vendor package. If we really need to, I suggest to either have our own clone (say, on github) and vendor that, or to import it locally and check it in outside the vendor'ed directory (which is much less preferable).

But whatever we choose, it should not be updated "inline" and there are many good reasons for it (one of them highlighted by Yacov above, indeed).

Given the two options (github or a local, non-vendor'ed directory checked-in under the same branch) I wonder if we really need this (inline) change to the vendor'ed code?
we should under no circumstance be modifying vendored code. submit a change upstream and lobby for it to be merged and a new version published.

data.commitMessage:
Add support for cop client reenroll

This allows a user to renew a certificate by adding
support for the following command:
 cop client reenroll <copServerURL>
This is similar to the enroll command which is
 cop client enroll <enrollmentID> <enrollmentSecret> <copServerURL>
except that the reenroll uses token-based authentication rather than
basic auth.

More specifically, the authorization header of the request contains
a token which has a signature created from the private key of the
current enrollment certificate.  This allows a certificate to be
refreshed by the owner of the current certificate.  The body of a
reenroll request has a CSR just as the body of a enroll request.

Since there was a good bit in common between enroll and reenroll,
I rearranged some code to enable code sharing between the 2 paths.
In particular, some of the code from under the cli/client package
was moved to the lib package to allow it to be shared by enroll,
reenroll, or any other commands in the future.

See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1147

Change-Id: I350a8bf8a700550e58b44beadc9a9af173cc2fee
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: The reason I had a check to see if it was json file was because you could potentially have "loglevel=0" as the last argument.
loglevel=0 isn't recognized.  We should use the COP_DEBUG variable to set this.
You probably don't need all this after my latest changeset moved the DBaccessor has part of the config object. I believe that changeset has been merged.
Shall we also print out/log the error somehow?
Jonathan, cfssl code already prints the error.  I actually did that initially but it was double logging it.
Oh, I see. Good to know, thank you.
Hmmm.... what does VerifyToken() return now?
The 1st arg is a pointer to an x509.Certificate, but it is not needed in this context.  Actually, if you look at the revocation changeset (2843), I do use it there.

Maybe: "Reenroll request was handled successfully" ?

(We can leave as 'reenroll' if you prefer. Both work here, I see why)
BTW: This change was not included in your recent patchset. Not a biggy, just to let you know.
BTW: What is this hardcoded/non-configurable name?
This function is only used for test case execution.  See the comment at the top.
Yes, saw this. Thanks. Let's see, maybe it will be useful to be able to configure these too at some point. LGTM

(I know that it's the default in CFSSL, ...)

Do we have plans to change it/make it configurable, or so?

We do plan on making the default https rather than http.  This will be coming soon in a change set.
I wasn't thinking of changing the default port, though maybe we should go with standard 443.  We would then have to override the defaults for test cases no running as root to work on server side.

It is configurable by providing a 'config' string similar to:
   {"serverURL": "https://localhost"}
Thank you. Sounds good. We can discuss that configuration/changeset over a separate JIRA. I think that would be useful.
Hold on, should we not return 'err2' here, not 'err', right?
Let's make it a sentence describing the status. "The request to Register ..."
Yes, this makes much more sense to me now (to have a public getter). Thank you.
Similarly, this makes much more sense to me now (to have a public getter). Thank you.

What does this flag mean please?

Documented anywhere?

This was intended to be used only during development so that folks could make progress before the authentication framework was in place.  It is used by in cli/server/auth.go to by-pass authentication for all endpoints.  I'll remove it from this and any other files but prefer to leave the functionality there for at least now just in case we need it.  The default value is of course true.

Thank you.

BTW: If it is still useful (say, while in development), we can still have this and just document it briefly.

Not sure I understand what's "Error in parsing x509 cert given Block Bytes"...

Mind you, the user has no clue that we have a temporary variable called 'block'.
Changing to reuse err variable.  It is an error type.  Also reviewed/improved error messages and use of error variables elsewhere in this module.
Yes, I saw the improvement. Thanks Keith.

>>
"The register request [completed] successfully"

data.commitMessage:
Add support for certificate revocation

This is part 1 of supporting certificate revocation.
Certificate revocation consists of the following parts:
1) Revoke a single certificate identified by serial number, adding to CRL list of COP server only.
2) Revoke all certificates associated with an enrollment ID (COP server only) and disable the enrollment ID.
3) Add revoked certificate serial numbers to the ledger's CRL list.
4) Prune the ledger's CRL list for certificates that have expired

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-116

Change-Id: Idab965c05998b447ba004b44b72a8c06b555dabf
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

Saad is working on extending the schema of the certificates table with an enrollment ID column to allow me to do this search.  But yes, this section of code will be enhanced in a future change set.

data.commitMessage:
Store COP enrollment artifacts in MSP friendly way

Instead of storing all enrollment artifacts in a single
client.json file, store it in separate key and store files.
This is inline with MSP (Membership Service Provider) APIs.
The enrollment certificate is stored at `$COP_ENROLLMENT_DIR/cert.pem`
by default, but a different path can be specified by setting
the `COP_CERT_FILE` environment variable.
The enrollment key is stored at `$COP_ENROLLMENT_DIR/key.pem`
by default, but a different path can be specified by setting
the `COP_KEY_FILE` environment variable.
The default value of the `COP_ENROLLMENT_DIR` environment
variable is `$COP_HOME`.
The default value of the `COP_HOME` environment variable
is `$HOME/cop`.

See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1353

Change-Id: I77625acefad9365a345dc107d94ddf6c86e877c1
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: I don't think that we should use a hidden directory for these.

That said, I'm OK either way and will go ahead and change it to "$HOME/cop", but just trying to understand.   Thanks.

Done.
Do we want to also mention how that (cert) file can be specified (e.g., absolute/relative, etc.).
This is a repeat of lines 252-26 0above...
Is client a pointer? Shall we check/validate before attempting to use?

Let's change:
"// GetDB returns the database handle"

To:
// GetDB returns a handle to an established driver-specific database connection

data.commitMessage:
Enforce validity period in COP for ECerts/TCerts

This change set verifies that a certificate has neither
expired nor been revoked.  The main change is a relatively
small change in auth.go which calls cfssl code to verify the
cert.

The test case uses a special signing profile which expires after
1 second.  To support this, I had to make a change so that the
enroll and reenroll commands support using a non-default signing profile.
Therefore, I changed what goes across the network of an enroll
and reenroll request.  Prior to this change, it only sends
a CSR.  After this change, it sends JSON with a CSR and an
optional signing profile name (along with other optional fields).

I have notified the SDK folks of this change.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-145

Change-Id: Idceeedadf9e5a42d995feee5bdba1353b685e9f1
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

This is still needed to check the err return from util.GetEnrollmentIDFromPEM

nit here - but looks like you can get here via both the enroll and reenroll paths so I'd suggest replacing "reenroll" with either "enroll/reenroll" or 
"(re)enroll" in here and on the next line as well
I cleaned this up by storing the endpoint name in the handler struct and putting it altogether in enroll.go and just deleting reenroll.go.  This seems cleaner to me and also logs the correct message.

data.commitMessage:
More tcert library APIs prior to COP integration

This contains more tcert library APIs to enable code
reuse and also to minimize the change set size.
In particular, there are some more utility functions and
one new object in keytree.go.  This will be used to generate
a tree of derived keys for affiliation groups.

The next change set which will shortly follow will
integrate the tcert library into the COP server and client.

The changes to cli/cop_test.go were necessary to fix transient
test failures.  There is no need to start a server when testing
cop.go to get test coverage, so I simplified test cases.
The server and client commands are tested under server and client
packages respectively, where an actual server is started.

See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-876

data.commitMessage:
Integrate TCert library into COP server and client

This change set integrates the tcert library APIs into the COP server
and client.  The main server-side tcert code is in cli/server/tcert.go.
There is very little client-side tcert code, but it is in lib/identity.go.

In future change sets we will:
1) Integrate BCCSP
2) Simplify the object structure and naming in lib.  The abstraction
   was originally done to accomodate other providers, but this abstraction
   was pushed to MSP, so we will simplify COP.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-876

Change-Id: If7b73d6411ab205a3680a977b9a8cd09e57e81d0
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: I think Keeping NewKeyTree as a function outside of TCert will make it more loosely coupled. To me , it does seem benign.

This is just a suggestion : We need to make sure that when client makes a request for TCerts , it sings the request corresponding to ECert. Alternatively , we might add ECert as parameter which comes over wire , so GetPrivateSigner should be extended to add ECert.I prefer second approach as we cannot force client to use ECERT for signing purposes.Your thoughts ?

The auth.go wrapper already verifies the signature over the certificate + the body of the request before tcert.go is called.  It does this for all calls, not just the request for tcerts ... well, except for enroll which uses basic auth.
Fine for now. Will revisit later.

See 'bccspBackedSigner' at https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3679/6/cli/server/bccspsigner.go for an implementation of this.
2) A small change in CFSSL's universal.go to allow COP to prepend bccspBackedSigner to the 'localSignerList'.

Patch Set 4:

Thinking more about this, I guess I am really trying to understand why we need to use BCCSP at all?  From a signing perspective, combining CFSSL with the LetsEncrypt pkcs11key package would give us HSM support.   Perhaps it might need to be slightly extended if we want to do encryption using the HSM as well as signing

Patch Set 4:

Gari: I did some searching into the claim that CFSSL supports PKCS11. The CFSSL docs think that PKCS11 is supported, but that is not true. Tag 1.1.0 was almost there (would had been close enough for us I guess) but it appears it never was completely true:

See https://github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/issues/247
That one was opened against Tag 1.1.0
See https://github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/blob/1.1.0/signer/universal/universal.go#L66 how pkcs11key was inserted, which is what Keith submited back to CFSSL as pull request

Seems the pkcs11 support was almost there, except for the few holes pointed out by https://github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/issues/254

--------
In the CFSSL master branch and 1.2.0 tag, they went and completely stripped out pkcs11key from cfssl and moved it out to its own repo. Great. Except they also stripped the CLI HSM options, Config fields to specify HSM key-tags, ways to build Universal and OCSP signer out of crypto.Signer interface and probably a few more things that I forget.

In short, CFSSL has no support for pkcs11key
--------

Fine, why not put it back? Well. Here is what I thought is a good reason: if Fabric core is using BCCSP, shouldn't we try to keep things more uniform and use BCCSP everywhere? I am getting more and more requests for 'can we do this with that crypto library/algorithm' (i.e. FIPS and other regional requirements; requests to use this library or that library). The only scalable answer I see is to make crypto pluggable in the longer term. This is a step to that goal.

Patch Set 4:

Gari, another reason is that we already wanted to use BCCSP's key derivation for tcerts to consolidate fabric code, so using one crypto primitive package for everything in COP seems desirable.

Patch Set 4:

Gari , I am just reiterating Vlad's point. The main reason I see for Cosolidation of crypto primitive at one place is for Compliance and Export Regulations perspective.

I'll just say that LetsEncrypt gets this to work.  But that's all I'll say there

Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

> Gari, another reason is that we already wanted to use BCCSP's key
 > derivation for tcerts to consolidate fabric code, so using one
 > crypto primitive package for everything in COP seems desirable.

Right - but key derivation has nothing to do with HSM integration - that's my only point.  And part of the idea is reducing the amount of custom code.  Perhaps its fine to do something like pkcs11key which wraps up BCCSP.  I just don't want to see us changing the CFSSL signing code (which at the end of the day is using the crypto.Signer interface

Patch Set 4:

Gari, I wasn't saying that key derivation has anything to do with HSM.  That is one reason for separating BCCSP integration and HSM into separate change sets.  This is the change set for allowing BCCSP to used for any purpose at all by COP.  I think the real question pertaining to this change set is, should we use BCCSP in the COP server for any reason at all?  I think it was desirable to minimally use the key derivation function in BCCSP for TCerts rather than maintaining two sets of code which do the same thing, in bccsp and what is currently in lib/tcert/tcert.go, which BTW still has hard-coded values in for specific algorithm/key size.  So instead of generalizing that code, I wanted to just use BCCSP.

I know this doesn't apply to Vlad's change set, but just wanted to limit it to this change set.

Thanks

data.commitMessage:
COP BCCSP integration

This is the first step of integrating BCCSP into COP.
One of the purposes is to provide HSM support.

In particular, this change set:
1) Adds the lib/csp package which support BCCSP configuration
2) Uses lib/csp to initialize BCCSP in the COP server

The next step will be use the BCCSP for TCerts for two reasons:
a) we can't use cfssl to do TCert key derivation;
b) the current lib/tcert/tcert.go code has hard-coded algorithm
   and key length.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1461

Change-Id: Icdc286118fe2c61d907046e8083e318fd85e5e77
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

data.commitMessage:
COP API simplification

See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1462 for
a description of what was done in this change set.
This draws clean lines around the client library API
defined in api/client.go verses the REST APIs of what
goes over the network in api/net.go, which defines
the body of POST and responses.  This should help in
generating swagger doc for the REST APIs.

Note that the tcert library at lib/tcert has it's own
API in lib/tcert/api.go also.

Change-Id: Idb4500b3a5dbc04dfeb65d5b79f8b803411d975f
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: This is not required. The reason is : If client does not need key derivation , they will populate keySigPair field in net.go. Please remove this.

Ash, I didn't want the user of the library to have to generate the key pairs themselves.  This is handled by the fabric-cop library.  We don't yet have a golang SDK, but when we do, this is more user-friendly to do it this way.

ok. May be I need to understand the flow better.I think , this will be consumed by Node SDK and Java client as of now.

The way I understand the flow is client API wants to generate TCert , they populate GetTCertBatchRequest struct and then call REST end point. So by the time , for TCert option 2 call , they need batch of signature block. This field does not fit into this flow.
Discussed with Ash and he is OK

Ash, since this is what flows over the network, we need to be opaque and extensible with respect to the type of signature.  If we needed to add a new signature type to your structure, it would change the network structure and we would then get a deserialization error.  If however we needed to support a new signature algorithm, the KeySig structure does not need to change, so the network structure doesn't change.

Also, we don't need a payload other than the public key.  We prove ownership of the key is enough because we already have another signature over the payload of the request.

We should be mindful of server capability also.We cannot add signature on the fly. CoP should have that capability for new signature type also.
My structure depicts CoP's capabilities more clearly and it is verbose so that it minimizes chance of error.
Thirdly , getting BYTE out of Crypto objects adds another level of crypto capability on client. 

In the event of advent of new signature type , our swagger doc will change once you implement new signature type.I do not see any reason for deserialization error in that case.

Maybe , I am missing something. I feel much comfortable with what I have checked-in. Thanks.
Discussed with Ash and he is OK
Please add this element : PublicKeys [][]byte `json:"public_keys,omitempty"`. That is required for TCert Option 2. Thanks.
Ash, I agree, but you can add this field in your change set.

Ash, actually we do not need this change.  I forgot about a comment I mentioned earlier.  The only thing we need to call in lib/tcert is to get the cert extensions.  Everything else can be done with a small amount of code in cli/server/tcert.go.

My assumption was that APIs provides documentation also.For that reason , I want this field to be present here.

The coding has already been done for this part. Please look at https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3817/. It is working code , so no need to write new code.
why are we logging the error here, rather than wherever we catch it?
Agreed.  I've been trying to clean these up but missed this one.  Done
why are you using fmt.Errorf with a message that does not use any formatting of arguments?
There is no fmt.Error, and I found it more consistent to just use fmt.Errorf always much like we use C's printf even without format arguments.  That said, I'm changing to error.New as you prefer.
why are we logging the error here rather than where we catch it?
why are we logging the error here rather than where it is caught?
there is still function associated with signer.go - it needs unit tests
unit tests for signer.go are in client_test.go because we need to drive those tests by starting a server once in the package ... anyway, they are covered.

Default name of COP executable should be cop, not cli

    go get github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cop/cop
will install the COP executable rather than requiring users to
do the following

    mv $GOPATH/bin/cli $GOPATH/bin/cop
We can delete the duplicate code in fabric-cop/cli at a later
date but am leaving it for now to make sure we don't break
any scripts.

Patch Set 4:

Just goin from the README, I wasn't able to
get it to work out of the box.

In order to make it work for me I had to
1 - create a shell wrapper that replaces the _TAG_,
    then calls docker build with explicit docker file
    and modified context:
      #!/bin/sh
      CONTEXT=$GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cop/
      DOCKERFILE=$CONTEXT/docker/fabric-cop//Dockerfile.in
      _TAG_="$(uname -m)-$(cat $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/.baseimage-release)"
      sed -i "s/_TAG_/${_TAG_}/" $DOCKERFILE
      docker build -f $DOCKERFILE -t fabric-cop $CONTEXT

     Note that this also implies that the fabric has been cloned,
     since it used the same mechanism that fabric uses to
     generate the TAG


2 - I also had trouble with the context and relative directories.
    I set CONTEXT to
       "$GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric-cop/"
    and re-wrote the src file paths for the COPY cmds
   +COPY bin/cop $GOPATH/bin/
   +COPY docker/fabric-cop/cop.json /config/cop.json
   +COPY docker/fabric-cop/cop-psql.json /config/cop-psql.json
   +COPY docker/fabric-cop/csr.json /config/csr.json
   +COPY docker/fabric-cop/ec-key.pem /root/.cop/ec-key.pem
   +COPY docker/fabric-cop/ec.pem /root/.cop/ec.pem

3 - COPY bin/cop $GOPATH/bin/ presumes that cop has already
    been built, so it should be stated that this step has
    been done previous to the docker build, or we make cop
    as part of the build. I favor the latter.

3 - Perhaps we can simplify the paths somehow? might be good
    just to grab the config from testdata, if the CONTEXT
    is now set up two levels

data.commitMessage:
FAB-1214: Generates a fabric-cop image for docker

This commit includes the Dockerfile used for generating
a docker image as well as a docker-compose file for
setting up a cop server and 3 separate clients.

Change-Id: Id85eb44d7febb7e483c56068b75f727d29126adc
Signed-off-by: Latitia M Haskins <latitia.haskins@gmail.com>

comments.message: I think it would be better for us to expose all of the options as ENVIRONMENT variable so that we can use the same image and mount our own external volume for the require config files
can you also take a look at the work Greg Haskins did in the main repo?  Might be good to follow that bath for basically binary only COP, but this is OK for now given where we are

Yes, this was implemented this way to get something going that we can use. I definitely want this to look different for the dev environment. This allowed us to get a docker image that we could use. 

In order to remove any confusion I can move this Dockerfile to a different repo or directory for use in non-dev environments and have the default be used in dev environment to be built by a make command (similar to fabric Dockerfile builds).

Thoughts?
So the idea for this image is to build an image using the latest committed code?
Yes, exactly. I will have one that we can use in our dev environments that I will push in a different patchset with changes for setting up cop clustering and postgres support (once that gets merged)
This should be set to true
Actually, it should be omitted.  The default is true and this was only for internal use, so we don't want to expose it.

I know BCCSP in fabric is currently hardcoded to assume this keypair, but that is temporary.  Don't we need to allow them to automatically generate it's key pair in general?  We will then need to extract the root certificate somehow to pass into the other images ... or we could add support for automatically downloading the root of trust from COP.

well I think that between cop and fabric we should agree on a long term default root certificate that both use by default and we can bake that one in.

you'll see that my other comment was on actually removing the file arguments from the cmd so that one could choose to mount and use their own 

A clever trick would be that you could mount a volume, then just run the CLI command via the container and then start your container pointing at the same volume

So what I'll do is include these certs in the build (for now), but allow the user to set the env vars to select what cert they want to use whether it's this set of certs or their own generated certs. I think having some default certs that we can use while they are hardcoded in the peer is helpful.

I think supporting 3 options would be good:
1) Use the default key/cert
2) Use the key/cert provided by an environment variable
3) Generate your own, which could be specified with another environment variable
If we only want to support 1 & 2 for now, fine, but wanted to mention 3.

#1 please try to keep lines to < 80 chars length
#2 use of /var/hyperledger/fabric seems unnecessary. Why are we looking there on the local machine to populate the contents of the generated Docker image? I would think that we would want to pick up the config info to be copied into the image from the development workspace. No?

#1 - will do.
#2 - This allows a user to be able to use their own config and certificate files as they see fit. I'll update the README to make this goal clearer.
this will create a problem building in CI, no? We will be picking up what has already been merged, we won't be picking up any changesets being processed through CI

Yes, this was for use for non-dev environments to be able to build a cop docker image. (It was being used for marbles demo and test environments.) 

I have a Dockerfile for dev environment in a separate changeset.

data.commitMessage:
FAB-1338: Docker-compose w/Clustering and Postgres

This change adds docker compose file for starting a network
of cop servers using haproxy and postgres

Change-Id: I07d3fb1455222fc51cd710f1260623ed9ba54a74
Signed-off-by: Latitia M Haskins <latitia.haskins@gmail.com>

comments.message: This is an x86 based Docker image and will break z and p.

Is there a docker image for postgres (and haproxy) for those specific environments that I can reference using an architecture tag? If not, how would you recommend building one for use as needed when running this for those environments?

You can try sinenomine/postgresql-s390x for postgres on z.
https://store.docker.com/community/images/sinenomine/postgresql-s390x

Your can try sinenomine/origin-haproxy-base for haproxy on z.
https://store.docker.com/community/images/sinenomine/origin-haproxy-base

I'm not sure what is available for p (Power).

One way to go about this is to use the fabric-baseimage and create your own postgress and haproxy images for the tests. You could have Dockerfiles for p and z that would install the necessary components (e.g., postgress, haproxy, etc.) on top of the fabric-baseimage.
This build used x86 based docker images and will break z and p.
if the compose file is intended to be used for testing the current build, then I think that we should be explicitly specifying the _TAG_ and re-writing the compose as a function of the build.

Especially when testing, why would we not just use the latest build by default? If someone wants to use a specific tag, they can set it in the list of docker images or change the tag here - however they choose. I think by default we should use the latest image.

We need to use the _TAG_ approach so that a) we can support multi-architecture testing (see John's comments) and b) so that we can use the output of a specific build, not necessarily the latest.

I still maintain that we want to use a re-write of the compose file for integration, scale and performance testing.
Ah. Makes sense in regards to it's use in CI. I'll make the necessary changes.
This is an x86 based docker image and will break both z and p.
This is an x86 based Docker image and will not work with z or p.
Not sure why Dockerfile exists if the intent is to create a Dockerfile from Dockerfile.in.  This is an x86-based Docker image and will not work with z or p.

data.commitMessage:
fix code coverage report issue

Added checks target in makefile to perform all checks in go
and updated unit-tests target now verifying checks first then
executing unit-tests

Change-Id: I3ab379e2de4dd38df814c7e8bfce42781c5649aa

comments.message: How about replacing this list with "checks" now?
Please add coverage.xml to the .gitignore file so that we don't check it in.
@keith, this change was merged in previous change set.
We have another package that needs to be excluded (/server/dbutil). However, it has not been merged yet. Should we go ahead add the exclusion now or wait?
@skarim, my take is we should not skip any packages other than vendor.. So that it just prints "no test files" if the package doesn't have any unit-tests.

I agree about not skipping other folders, btw.

More generally, I believe that the less we "customize" with exceptions the better. We will start with one and then another, and before we know it, we will end up with an external file listing all of them "exceptions".

Long term, it will be easier to maintain going forward, and will also be "cleaner" in the sense that we know the rules of what lead to a CI signed "SUCCESS". A more straight-forward/transparent ruleset, that is easy to reproduce externally/understand without any "magic".

Unfortunately it looks like gerrit/git is not recognizing files which were simply moved to a different directory and instead shows as a delete and an add.  For example, everything under "lib/defaultImpl" is now under "lib" directly, because COP by definition will have only a single implementation given the APIs are defined in fabric.  We also removed the "cli/cop" directory and moved everything under it up one level, because we will only have one executable (cop) delivered.
I didn't realize that it wouldn't recognize moving files and allow a simple delta.  The bottom line is that 98% of the code changes are new tests and changing the Makefile to ensure test coverage going forward.  Changing the directory structure makes it look like more.  I'm not sure what to do at this point to make it easier to review, because putting the old directory structure back would be a step back.

Testcases added to support better test coverage

More testcases have been added for registering and
enrolling a user, and also for util functions to provide
better test coverage. Make file now checks to see
if there is 75% test coverage for each package. If not,
it will return appropriate message.

Code was also reorganized and directory structure was changed.
Filenames all use lowercasing now.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-862

Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: I think I have reviewed and corrected it when this was in the fabric/ca branch... can we incorporate the suggestions?
Let's use Golang standard file naming conventions. I don't know this got merged with an _. Can you please fix?
Shall we name the file differently, to match the DBAccessor (rather than database_accessor) ?
'N" for consistent capitalization at the beginning, please.
You must be kidding!  This is a debug message.  Why does this matter??

Keith, I am not entirely sure what gave you the (wrong) impression that I "must be kidding!". Even debug messages should be grammatically correct and well formatted.

That said, looking at the "grand scheme of things": this is the least important comment/suggestion made in the initial partial review of ours (way after the licensing/commit message, error checking, standard const/file names, etc.) - and it is not why we gave it a "-2" after careful examination. Will highly appreciate it, if you could prioritize/address the other comments as well.


---

p.s. I'm sorry, but I must say that I don't like the tone of your comment/response.

I am truly sorry for any inconvenience my review has caused. When I see issues, I post them (consistently), as after a while staring at the same code, I get used to it, and I tend to miss the "first impression" effect that I have when I read (new) code for the first time.

<amiably>
   This is just how my (limited) brain works.
</amiably>

Sorry Jonathan for any perceived tone. I was simply a truly surprised response and appreciate the time you spend reviewing.

WRT this comment, we will change the debug message "register request received" to "Register request received".  Does this mean that all debug messages should begin with uppercase?  Is this documented somewhere?

Any reason why we don't look at the returned error (and later on return "tok" which may be invalid?).

If there's a good reason, let's document. Otherwise, let's add the error checking.
Capitalization + maybe some context if/as it's for debugging?

What's "hf" ?

Also, a non-boolean flag/var/const should probably not be called isRegistrar...

Noted, thank you. Not sure if you would like it capitalized then (Like the HFC we talked about back in the day for Hyperledger Fabric Client)... but up to you.

I'd focus on the const/var name. Thanks.

1. Design, Design, Design:
Why do we keep on changing package names in every other check-in?
Can we please have a design document, listing out the proposed packages?

2. Also, let's use a standard Golang file naming convention. Not sure why we started camelcase naming in this instance ["temporalSigner.go"]

Jonathan, this is an implementation of an API.  Why does it matter if the package names are moved?  The corresponding factory was changed to reference this new location and there is no difference from a user perspective.  BTW, the reason this was done was to flatten the directory structure since the APIs will be part of fabric and COP will have only a single implementation.  We also flattened the directory structure in some places to make it easier to avoid circular dependencies AND to get test coverage to report for the correct package.

Jonathon, I assume you are saying the filename should be all lowercase (temporalsigner.go). I don't think we want to use an underscore, right? This is what I found regarding file naming conventions in go: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25161774/what-are-conventions-for-filenames-in-go

go -> Go 

or 

"No 'go vet' problems found"

I'm not sure whether you'd like to make the certificate public?
While we have a  'getMyCert()' getter method (which is not public?). 

Saad, please could you double-check/advise?
Good catch! It should have been public and we will address it.

Now I'm not sure we need the getter, as it is public, but let's go ahead and revisit as we make more process (and see what's the best way).

(A lot is happening at the same time and I appreciate it)

comments.message: Why are you attaching an instance of DBAccessor to the Config object?   Shouldn't it be part of the Server instance?
I made it part of Config cause a pointer to the config object is available to both the registering, bootstrapping, and enrolling code.
I don't think we should have the DB type as part of a/the function's name... Being SQLite or otherwise.
We are working to abstract out the database name. We have a user story out there for this effort. https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1144
Seems as if the _ is new. Do we want to establish/introduce a new database column naming scheme? (and apply it consistently...over all tables/columns?)
Yes, the underscore was the only thing change.
I am not sure I understand.
I mean, let's document this function too.

This is not exactly what the function is doing.

Are we updating the config pointer inside the function? E.g.line 130.

Later you bootstrap a new one, etc...
A repeat, I know: I don't think this is a flexible enough function name/signature.
We should really be consistent with whichever name you choose. I thought the latest is/was COP (and the binary is 'cop') ?
I don't know what this message means.
I am not sure why it would.
This should be true by default
I'm curious why this is in util.  Shouldn't all DB stuff be under cli/server as it is server-specific?
there should probably be some type of dbutils package and/or struct assuming we'll support other databases as well?

Yes, I think having a separate dbutil for database specific functions is a good idea. Database specific code is only necessary for connecting to a database or seeing if it already exists. The sql queries are all the across databases.

A clarification from patchset 1. How about:

Enroll encapsulates the Config and functionality needed for user enrollment
The function name is "SignerFromConfig[AndDB]" but I'm not sure we should print that out.

[F]ailed in SignerFromConfig[AndDB]

But I don't believe we should really print out the internal function/implementation name in the error.

How about:

"Could not find and validate group '" + group + "' [" + err +"]"

data.commitMessage:
Group Prekey, Serial Number, and Max Enrollments

A prekey is generated for a group when a new group is created
and is stored in the groups table. Serial number and AKI has
been added to the users table and it will hold the serial number
and AKI for the current certificate for an enrolled. A configuration
option for repeated enrollment request by a user has been added. User
will be allowed a certain number of maximum enrollments which will
be specified in the server configuration file.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-943
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-983

Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: why exactly are we adding this field here?  I thought there was a plan to try to add the user name / enrollId in the certificates table?
This will contain the most recent serial number and AKI issued to the user. The enrollment id will be added to the certificates table as well that is just for making auditing easier.
More specifically, both a SerialNumber and AKI are required in order to retrieve a certificate from the certificate's table, so this allows us to retrieve the most recent one for the user.
sure but if you are going to modify the certDB to get certificates by user, then why include this data here as well?

You're right of course.  As long as we pass the actual certificate in the authorization header along with the signature (which we currently do as shown by the code below from auth.go), I can't think of why we would ever need the SerialNumber or the AKI in the users table.  So Saad, I think both can be deleted.

                // check status of certificate
                serial := cert.SerialNumber.String()
                aki := hex.EncodeToString(cert.AuthorityKeyId)
                certs, err := CFG.certDBAccessor.GetCertificate(serial, aki)
cool - that was my thinking as well.  I would just hate to have to do multiple reads / writes as well as worry about keeping things in sync between tables if we can avoid it
Saad  -any reason not to remove SerialNumber and AKI here?
what does this change have to do with the actual intent of the changeset?
We are adding AKI to the users table so this function gets the AKI for a certificate.
Some/all of these fields do not belong in config or they should have a json label.  They will be cleaned up in a later change set.  See https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1347
FYI, the update of the user registry is done in auth.go, thus removed here.

A nit, but all occurrences of "registery" should be replaced with "registry" and "Registery" with "Registry".  This is in several debug messages, variable names, etc.  I'm wondering if some earlier review comments have been lost somehow or was this fixed in a later change set perhaps?

Please remove this option as we don't even want to document it and will probably remove it soon.  Authentication should always be enabled.  We added this option temporarily during start up.  It seems that it continues to be added back somehow.
You checked these tcertResponse files in by mistake.  Pls delete.
Do you have a test case with max enrollments > 1?  If not, pls add.

data.subject: Group Prekey, Serial Number, and Max Enrollments

Extend CFSSL accessor to support ID in Cert table

Extend CFSSL DB accessor to support adding enrollment ID to
certificates table. A column in the certificates table will
be added for enrollment ID, each certificate will have an ID
associated with it.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1294

Change-Id: I144ca1debb12950eb35536546231528af42f50da
Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Keith Smith <bksmith@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: The condition should be if id=:id and status != "revoked", because we don't want to lose the time at which it was initially revoked.
I think you need to delete this since multiple rows can be affected

I suggest just returning the number of rows affected from this function.  There are cases where 0, 1, or multiple may be legitimately affected, so it is up to the caller to determine which ones (if any) are errors.
Correction, I need you to return an array of the certificates that were revoked.
we should probably call this CertDBAccessor and rename the file given that this is really for certdb
What does this mean? Is this documented that you default to 1 ?
Allows you to specify how many times a user can use its one time password to enroll itself. I updated the Readme about it.

Thank you.

What I do/did not like is the fact that it switches from 0 to 1 (as it's not intuitive). I suggest to either have 0 interpreted as "unlimited", or alternatively, to break if the MaxEnrollments is not a positive number.
I've made it so now that we interpret zero as infinite.
This is temporarily commented it out. It needs to be reintroduced when some of the depending code is finished.
OK, if it makes it easier. In general, it's OK to just use the versioning system (git, or so, for these).
The signature of the function states that it expects only an error (one)

1. I can't tell when we use CFG and when we don't... so now we use the CFG and for UserRegistry we don't?

2. This should all be in JIRA or in the commit message(s).

3. Does this have to be part of this changeset (to extend the CFSSL...)?

1. CFG is going to be strictly used for what is defined in the server config file (cop.json). There is some clean up happening to strictly enforce that rule. UserRegistry was moved out of the config object. 

3. No this was just some clean up that was done.
We want them to be available to the entire package
OK, let's move on and see if we can refrain from these (somehow).

1. Why do you need the temporary?
2. If you are changing from NewCffslAccessor to NewCertDBAccessor(), let's change the variable.
3. (a repeat): Why are you introducing these "package level" global variables?

1. Its not temporary, the function does two thing. One it return an interface that CFSSL needs. Second it sets a global variable that is a pointer to the accessor which is used for making DB calls that CFSSL doesn't support. 

2. Done

3. Cause these are database accessor. Db access might be required in multiple places in the package such as for register, enroll, revoke functionality.

In 1, I meant the temporary variable "certDBAccessor".
2. Thanks.
3. Yes, let's keep these, and we'll take a look to see if we can avoid these (using interfaces).
I don't think we should use HOME, at all.
Jonathan, why not use HOME?  This is used by other clients, such as the "cf" CLI for cloudfoundry.

The HOME (in Linux/UNIX is used by so many things, e.g., reset by Telnet, and so many others).

Would rather have something more specific, JAVA_HOME (which clearly belongs to one's JAVA settings or the "MEMBERSRVC_CA_" prefix as an example for something we used earlier to avoid potential collisions, while making it clear that stuff belongs to ""MEMBERSRVC...." etc. Same goes for JAVA and many others).

In general, I would always rather have a more intuitive and explicit error messaging, over storing a hidden (".cop") repository in a user's domain without their knowledge. While clearly this was not the intention, it may bite us back.
Can we discuss this outside of this changeset. The intention of this changeset is not around this.

I am sure I have objected to this before/at some point. Please let's not write to "production" especially if someone has not set HOME.

The default (for someone who hasn't read the manual, for example, and so has not set the env variable) should be "dev" or "test" at best. E.g.,

/var/hyperledger/fabric/dev/.fabric-cop
Still waiting for a response for this, but thinking it over - we also don't really need to have it "hidden" either way (be it dev or test)
Sorry, forgot to change it here. I'll fix that.
You are converting to an x509 Certificate
If this function supports only Certificate(s), then let's call it as such.
Please can we read also the DER part?

Jonathan, I wrote this and gave it to Saad, so he was asking me what to do here.  I'm not sure I understand either.  Are you proposing that we make the function more general so that it accepts either a PEM or a DER encoding?  In that case, we'll need to change the function name also.  Please clarify.

The way PEM is decoded, is iteratively/recursively:
That is, you fetch a block, and keep the "rest" (DER), use the block, then decode the "rest" (DER), and so forth

The current code:

1. Errors/throws/complains about not being able to parse a certificate, before we tried to parse the block,
, and another issue is tha,
2. It ignores the "rest" after the first iteration.

---

But I can just follow up with another changeset, it it is easier.
Yeah, I think Keith was checking this in as part of one of his changeset. Perhaps the changes can be addressed there.
Potentially misleading: the failure here has nothing to do with a certificate (yet). The package you are using simply reads a block from text (bytes).

EnrollmentID

(let's keep it a "term", as per the original documentation/design docs)

EnrollmentID

(let's keep it a "term", as per the original documentation/design docs)
I think this should simply be "if u.maxEnrollments > 0", right?  If the limit is infinite, then there is no reason to increment the number of enrollments in the DB.
Actually, on 2nd thought, this is correct because if the maxEnrollments is changed, we still need to enforce it for previously enrolled users.
Is this 2 database updates?  Any reason this couldn't be done in a single call?  This is the same table, right?
I've opened https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1442 to make this improvement in a future changeset.  It is not functionally incorrect as it is.
