data.commitMessage:
Add support for TLS and config file enhanced

TLS support for connection between client and COP server,
and COP server and database is now supported.

Simplified the cop server start command by reading the
CA cert and CA key from config rather than command line
parameters.

Cleaned up testcases to remove redundant code

README updated with instruction on how to configure TLS.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1383

Change-Id: I2a80b1844bcaa4ab0e2f9c3ec978f647406f99d7
Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: please limit line length to < 80 chars. Please fix all occurrences.
I assume that this is relative to the location of the binary? Is that the best idea?
Yes, but this is just an example. The user can place cert and key anywhere then specify the file path in the config file.
Saad, as an example, it would be better to just put "cop-cert.pem", unless this is part of a running example that really works.  Also note the extra space after "pem" in "../testdata/cop-cert.pem "
If you are really going to do something like this, I'd almost prefer that you copied the files rather than linking them.  Also, you should be using filepath.Join to instead of doing clientPath+"..."
Yeah, I looked into copying it but go doesn't provide any copy function and so it becomes more complicated to the file the copy over rather than just link it.
OK, to confirm: we are not linking these, right?
we should not be doing this.  also - if you are going to do something like enrollPath+"/cop_client.json" Go's filepath pkg (e.g. filepath.Join(...))
I think Chris meant: replace "didn't" with "doesn't" ;-)

Please let use a platform independent directory, using TempDir()
https://golang.org/pkg/io/ioutil/#TempDir

Also, let's have a fabric-cop or so as a prefix. Especially as later on this directory is being erased. We don't want collisions here.
I'm unclear what this is trying to accomplish

Link creates newname as a hard link to the oldname file. This is needed cause the client config file contains the location of client cert and key which is needed for a TLS connection. So this client config needs to be "copied" to the home directory which is what is being done here.
I am unclear WHY it needs to be copied.

The client code looks in the home directory for the client configuration file. This is something a user would create and place there manually. For testing purposes, I am just copying a test config file into the home directory.
What is the point of this?
It just to test a code path that is executed when COP_HOME is not set.

This is testing ONE code path, and there are in fact, 3 possible paths.
That said, I think that the whole concept is flawed, so whatever. I'll discuss with Gari and Jonathan.
Let's not hard-code it (again). It is declared at the top, so let's reuse it. If we call TempDir() then let's store its result, etc.
This is not the same directory path as the one hard coded. That directory will already exist when it hits this code, so I wanted to use a different one to test out the HOME environment variable.

This is why I suggest to not hard-code the /tmp/home folder.

It is declared at the top, so let's reuse it. If we call TempDir() then let's store its result, etc.

What was wrong with the original detailed error, or something along the lines of:
"Failed to get client TLS configuration: %s"
I think you must be looking at an older patch set, in the lastest patch set it is more detailed.
do we really expect multiple key pairs per client?
yeh, this does not need to be an array
In what format do you expect these KeyCertFiles ?
The client TLS config file is just a json file with paths to where cert and key are stored.

You should check the return value here (its a boolean) and return an error if you can't load one of the certs.   You could also loop through all the files, collect which ones fail and return all errors as well (but that's up to you as exiting on the first error found is fine as well)

All TLS server info should go in a subsection underneath "Start the COP server" section.  I suggest creating a subsection named similar to "cop.json file format" which has a sample cop.json and perhaps a reference table which describes all fields in the cop.json in more detail.
As mentioned above, let's move this and other TLS sections underneath "Start the COP server" section in a cop.json subsection.

Clean up Config structure

up. Several of the fields belong in the Server object, or if
they are config then they should have a JSON label.

comments.message: I would prefer a more explicit name for this package variable so that I can find it when I grep for it.  I suggest "enrollSigner".

2 thoughts on this:
1) Since it is only used in register.go, it would be better to add as a field in the registerHandler struct.
2) But it really isn't useful even in register.go.  If we have a cluster of COP servers, this mutex would not help.  The DB itself will handle serialization and your next change set will get rid of the separate UpdateField, so this should handle any concurrency issues.
So the bottom line is that you can just delete this mutex altogether.

data.commitMessage:
COP UserRegistry Consolidation

Remove UpdateField/GetField and replace with a single
GetUser and UpdateUser call. This will remove the need
to call both UpdateUser and UpdateField when updating a
field that was not initially part of the UserInfo struct
that was defined in the SPI. The UserInfo struct has been
expanded to support more fields.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1442

Change-Id: I1181a54a99bea42f4e6688f55c968798acec8025
Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: CFG.UsrReg.MaxEnrollments should be the max allowable enrollments for any user, but we should allow a registrar to register a user with less than this number of enrollments/logins if they choose.  I think this is a trivial change, but if not, feel free to open a Jira item to handle separately.
This make sense, I think it might be cleaner to handle in a seperate Jira item. I will create one.

If we add a field to the UserInfo, this means we have to remember to update this also.  We would not get a compile error if we forget.  I suggest adding a GetUserInfo method to the User interface in cli/server/spi/userregistry.go and implementing that method in various user registry implementations.  Then call user.GetUserInfo here and then just update the single State field before calling userRegistry.UpdateUser.
I'll work on this and make it part of this changeset.
We can delete GroupInfo and Group here, and the group.go and group_test.go files, right?  This is since we have added the GetAffiliationPath method.

I think we still need this. We still have a groups table, so I think this struct and interface are still helpful. I actually make use of these when I set the affiliation path for the user. If we eventually decide to get rid of the groups table down the road then I think we can abandon this.
At some point, I suggest to update to: "Failed to retrieve user info..."

data.commitMessage:
COP server throws NPE using config file to start

This reintroduces code that checks the config file
to see if CA Cert and CA Key are provided in the config
and uses those to start the server. However, if Cert and Key
are provided on CLI as well, CLI will take precedence over what is
defined in the COP configuration file.

Test cases enhanced to test both scenarios of starting
server from configuration file and cli.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1596

Change-Id: Iac6ca5e0a488032238b92ac327edbf8b411aeaf0
Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: So this means cop.db will always be created in the home directory.  I think folks expect all file names in the config file to be relative to the location of the config file itself.  Any reason for making this different?

If I didn't do this, it was creating cop.db in the testdata directory under fabric-cop. Then it has to be manually deleted. I guess I could change the config file from "cop.db" to be the absolute path somewhere else (such as cop home). Does it not make more sense to store the database in the cop home directory? What is cop home directory going to be used for?
Home directory should be used for the default location of the config file.
A nit, but let's define a global error variable in util or lib similar to "errNotImplemented = errors.New("NOT YET IMPLEMENTED")" and then use that in code and here.

Saad, I think you may be doing this in another change set, but if not, please move/consolidate this with the GetDefaultHomeDir function in fabric-cop/util/util.go.  They are currently in conflict and we only want one piece of code to get the home dir, as well as to create it.
Yes, I am handling this in another upcoming changeset.

I would discourage this as being the only option.  Looking forward to production, packagers/admins will generally want to direct the database path to something like /var/hyperledger/fabric-cop.  My suggestion is to minimally support an absolute path definition.  E.g. if CFG.DataSource starts with a leading "/", do not join to the homedir.
Greg, this was fixed in patch set 4.  It supports absolute or relative to the config file.

A nit, but line 263 and 265 are dups.
For clarity, recommend changing 263 to "os.Remove(COPDB)" and delete line 265.

data.subject: COP server throws NPE using config file to start

Patch Set 4:

> (1 comment)

That was the initial approach we wanted to go with as well. However, our CLI commands are built upon CFSSL's CLI implementation, so if we use -config flag there is CFSSL logic that checks for and requires that the config file contain a signing component. The signing component makes sense on the server side but not so much on the client, so that is why decided to go with the environment variable route.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

>> That was the initial approach we wanted to go with as well. 
[JL] Good!

>> However, our CLI commands are built upon CFSSL's CLI implementation, so if we use -config flag there is CFSSL logic that checks for and requires that the config file contain a signing component. 
[JL] I don't understand how is this an issue?? I understand that there is a CFSSL logic that requires a signing component in the config. OK.

>> The signing component makes sense on the server side but not so much on the client, so that is why decided to go with the environment variable route.

[JL] OK, so the server is signing requests. Good. Let's say the client does not. OK.

Now what I'm missing is the connection/relation to the review suggestion/request, that is:

How does the fact that "the server is signing requests" and/or that "the config needs to have a signing component" are an answer to "why do we have to use an environment variable and not a program argument for specifying such a config?"

Patch Set 4:

[Maybe] Are we suggesting that the server and the client require different configs? (server with a signing component, and client, without one)?

Patch Set 4:

I guess what I am going after here is a consistent way of doing things for config across both the client and the server.   

One thing that I had not considered is the fact that the "client" can be embedded as a library so in that case I can see using an env variable

Patch Set 4:

> [Maybe] Are we suggesting that the server and the client require
 > different configs? (server with a signing component, and client,
 > without one)?

Yes, that is right. It doesn't make sense to include a signing component on the client side config, as the server does the signing.

Patch Set 4:

> I guess what I am going after here is a consistent way of doing
 > things for config across both the client and the server.
Right this would have been the ideal way. But, CFSSL -config option did not allow the flexibility to not include signing component in the configuration file that you pass into this flag.

data.commitMessage:
COP Client Configuration File

COP client will now make use of a configuration file. This will
simply the CLI commands on the client side. An environment
variable needs to be defined that will reference the config file.

export COP_CLIENT_CONFIG = ../testdata/cop_client.json

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1622

Also, resolves absolute pathing on the client side.

https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1549

Change-Id: I985ed5744eb8baef2c40ebedb3b1e0abf0fc1696
Signed-off-by: Saad Karim <skarim@us.ibm.com>

comments.message: Looks like the "/" characters should be "|" here.  I assume you'll view in markdown viewer to verify it looks correct.
I am not sure why "|" shows up as "/" here. I have "|" locally.

Rather than returning an error, I think the default value for configFile should be
   path.Join(util.GetDefaultHomeDir(), "cop_client.json")

All of this code is identical across all client commands, except we don't call LoadMyIdentity in the enroll command.
I recommend creating a function in cli/client/util.go and putting this code in one place, and not returning an error if the COP_CONFIG_FILE env variable is not set per my previous comment.
The function can take a bool which states whether or not to call LoadMyIdentity, so it can be shared across all client commands.
This function probably isn't needed if you create the other shared function I mentioned earlier.
Shouldn't be relative to the home directory, right ... per other change set.

To join paths, would need to use "path.Join" normally.  However, here (and elsewhere below) we should be referencing fields in CFG (e.g. CFG.CACertFile).  In fact, I think configInit should set default values for these fields so you know they will never be "".
remove this "if".  You've already checked above.
add "return nil, err" on next line
Hmm ... does this change set need to be rebased or was there a bad merge on a rebase?  We no longer store the client key/cert in client.json, so this shouldn't be here.
Should't be here, but should have separate key and cert files.
Nice ... glad you moved it here where it belongs.
really picky I know, but pls format correctly since it's basically a sample.

why use an environment variable?   can't we be consistent and have a 
"-config" flag like for the server?

data.commitMessage:
Patch cryptoutil to use bccsp to sign certs

Use bccsp to load a key and use that key to create a signer for cert
signing

The main code is fairly straightforward, except for being exceedently
verbose (all that error checking) and the need for extra indirection via
SKI file (BCCSP abstracts away the concept of keystore)

Probably the more contentios part is the test updates. Test material had
generated private keys and certs. Proper way is to generate them through
the bccsp interface so it could work with any bccsp. As a way to make do,
import the pem key into bccsp and update the SKI file, so that further
tests can work.

Also updated bccsp to get the utils package
govendor update -tree github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/crypto/bccsp

Change-Id: I13a3dcbb2aee53735e2c78d0930d5fc9493096c0
Signed-off-by: Volodymyr Paprotski <vpaprots@ca.ibm.com>

comments.message:
Of course we can't always call GetDefault here.  What about having a csp file which contains json fields sufficient to construct both the BCCSP instance and the key.  For example, for the software implementation, the "key.csp" file might contain something similar to the following:

{
   "type": "SW",
   "ephemeral": "false",
   "keystore": "/tmp/keystore",
   "ski": "xxxxxx"
}

However we do this, these functions to load/store from/to file should be a part of BCCSP itself and usable both by fabic and COP.

data.subject: Patch cryptoutil to use bccsp to sign certs
